abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            the Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate
            that the demand survey for the Private Enterprise Support
            Project (PESP) resulted in an overestimation of credit
            demand and did not go far enough in identifying demand for
            specific lending products. The PESP required partial payment
            from enterprises for technical assistance. However, this
            component was not successful as enterprises, generally were
            not interested such assistance, perceiving the support
            either as a waste or available free of charge through grant
            financing. In the end, the project did not disburse any
            funds for this component. It is important to make sure that
            the implementation framework is clear from the outset of the
            project and that lines of authority are unambiguous. While
            the government has taken a number of important steps to
            strengthen the business environment, PESP enterprise surveys
            indicated a number of perceived deficiencies in the business
            environment continue to adversely affect private enterprise
            development. PESP had seven different task managers over an
            eight-year period. Such changes substantially disrupted
            project supervision, reduced institutional memory, and led
            to frequent shifts in approaches and strategies. Auditing
            remains a major issues for SME support projects in
            underdeveloped financial and banking sectors such as the
            Kyrgyz Republic.
